clinical_study.brief_title: Subcutaneous Rehydration Compared to Intravenous Rehydration
clinical_study.official_title: Subcutaneous Rehydration With Hylenex Compared to Intravenous Rehydration in Infants and Young Children With Mild to Moderate Dehydration

brief_summary.textblock: Randomized (1:1 ratio) study of subcutaneous (SC) versus intravenous (IV) fluid rehydration in mildly to moderately dehydrated pediatric patients.

detailed_description.textblock: This is a prospective, randomized (1:1 ratio), open-label, parallel group, multicenter, multi-national, study of SC versus IV fluid rehydration in mildly to moderately dehydrated pediatric patients treated in the Emergency Department (ED), inpatient pediatric unit, and/or outpatient urgent care facility. It is expected that up to 186 patients, in order to achieve 148 evaluable patients, will be randomized in a 1:1 ratio to receive isotonic fluid rehydration by either SC administration with hylenex (150 Units) or IV without hylenex.

primary_outcome.measure: Mean Total Volume of Fluid Administered at a Single Infusion Site, From the Start to the Cessation of Fluid Administration, for All Randomized Participants
primary_outcome.time_frame: During the infusion (single bolus dose of hylenex [1 hr], followed by subcutaneous fluid for 1 hour to 72 hours)
primary_outcome.description: It was anticipated that most participants in this study would be hydrated through only one infusion site. For participants who received fluid at more than one administration site, a single infusion site was defined as the anatomical site at which the majority of the total infusion volume was infused. The term "anatomical site" was designated as: 1) the back; 2) left thigh; 3) right thigh; 4) abdomen; or 5) chest.

primary_outcome.measure: Mean Total Volume of Fluid Administered at a Single Infusion Site, From the Start to the Cessation of Fluid Administration, for Non-rescued Participants
primary_outcome.time_frame: During the infusion (single bolus dose of hylenex [1 hr], followed by subcutaneous fluid for 1 hour to 72 hours)
primary_outcome.description: It was anticipated that most participants in this study would be hydrated through only one infusion site. For participants who received fluid at more than one administration site, a single infusion site was defined as the anatomical site at which the majority of the total infusion volume was infused. The term "anatomical site" was designated as: 1) the back; 2) left thigh; 3) right thigh; 4) abdomen; or 5) chest. Participants randomized to receive intravenous isotonic fluid were permitted to receive subcutaneous fluid administration by hylenex-facilitated infusion as rescue.

secondary_outcome.measure: Mean Total Volume of Fluid Administered at All Infusion Sites, From the Start to the Cessation of Fluid Administration, for All Randomized Participants Achieving > 200 mL
secondary_outcome.time_frame: During the infusion (single bolus dose of hylenex [1 hr], followed by subcutaneous fluid for 1 hour to 72 hours)
secondary_outcome.description: It was anticipated that most participants in this study would be hydrated through only one infusion site. For participants who received fluid at more than one administration site, a single infusion site was defined as the anatomical site at which the majority of the total infusion volume was infused. The term "anatomical site" was designated as: 1) the back; 2) left thigh; 3) right thigh; 4) abdomen; or 5) chest. The label for hylenex indicated precautionary wording recommending an upper limit on the volume of fluid (200 mL) administered subcutaneously to infants less than 3 years of age. In October 2008, the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) removed this wording from the label, thus negating the need for these data and associated analyses. The protocol was amended to reflect this label change; thus, this analysis was not conducted.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: During the infusion (single bolus dose of hylenex [1 hr], followed by subcutaneous fluid for 1 hour to 72 hours)

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of Participants Administered at Least 200 Milliliter (mL) Total Volume at a Single Infusion Site, From the Start to the Cessation of Fluid Administration
secondary_outcome.time_frame: During the infusion (single bolus dose of hylenex [1 hr], followed by subcutaneous fluid for 1 hour to 72 hours)
secondary_outcome.description: The number of participants administered at least 20 mL total volume was assessed.

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of Participants With the Indicated Type of Adverse Events
secondary_outcome.time_frame: up to 7 days after hospital discharge
secondary_outcome.description: Adverse events (AEs) are defined as any untoward medical occurrence in a participant administered a product, which did not necessarily have a causal relationship with the treatment. Treatment-emergent adverse events (TEAEs) are defined as those events that occurred on or after the first injection device insertion attempt.

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of Participants With Normal Physical Examination Findings at Baseline That Shifted to Abnormal at the End of Fluid Administration
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline; after infusion (single bolus dose of hylenex [1 hr], followed by subcutaneous fluid for 1 hour to 72 hours)
secondary_outcome.description: Baseline was defined as the time prior to the single site fluid infusion. End of infusion was defined as the end of infusion of the single site fluid infusion for participants who had more than one fluid infusion. Not Rel Dehy = Abnormal, Not Related to Dehydration; Rel Dehy = Abnormal, Related to Dehydration. The investigator assessed findings as abnormal.

secondary_outcome.measure: Mean Change From Baseline in Heart Rate
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline; after infusion (single bolus dose of hylenex [1 hr], followed by subcutaneous fluid for 1 hour to 72 hours)
secondary_outcome.description: Change from Baseline was calculated as the post-Baseline value minus the Baseline value. Baseline was defined as the time prior to the single site fluid infusion. End of infusion was defined as the end of infusion of the single site fluid infusion for participants who had more than one fluid infusion.

secondary_outcome.measure: Mean Change From Baseline in Respiratory Rate
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline; after infusion (single bolus dose of hylenex [1 hr], followed by subcutaneous fluid for 1 hour to 72 hours)
secondary_outcome.description: Change from Baseline was calculated as the post-Baseline value minus the Baseline value. Baseline was defined as the time prior to the single site fluid infusion. End of infusion was defined as the end of infusion of the single site fluid infusion for participants who had more than one fluid infusion.

secondary_outcome.measure: Mean Change From Baseline in Systolic Blood Pressure and Diastolic Blood Pressure
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline; after infusion (single bolus dose of hylenex [1 hr], followed by subcutaneous fluid for 1 hour to 72 hours)
secondary_outcome.description: Change from Baseline was calculated as the post-Baseline value minus the Baseline value. Baseline was defined as the time prior to the single site fluid infusion. End of infusion was defined as the end of infusion of the single site fluid infusion for participants who had more than one fluid infusion.

secondary_outcome.measure: Mean Change From Baseline in the Face, Legs, Activity, Cry, Consolability (FLACC) Pain Scale Score
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Before infusion (Baseline); after infusion (single bolus dose of hylenex [1 hr], followed by subcutaneous fluid for 1 hour to 72 hours)
secondary_outcome.description: The infusion site was assessed for pain at two time points: after placement of the infusion device but before fluid infusion and at the end of infusion. Pain was recorded using the FLACC pain scale for children less than 3 years of age. Scores on the scale ranged from 0 (no hurt) to 10 (hurt worst).

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of Participants With the Indicated Type of Fluid Administered
secondary_outcome.time_frame: During the infusion (single bolus dose of hylenex [1 hr], followed by subcutaneous fluid for 1 hour to 72 hours)
secondary_outcome.description: Data are reported for the initial fluid administered.

secondary_outcome.measure: Infusion Duration During the Initial Infusion
secondary_outcome.time_frame: first hour of infusion
secondary_outcome.description: Infusion duration was assessed as a measure of the time required to complete the initial infusion of 20 mL/kg.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change From Baseline in Hydration Status According to the Gorelick Assessment at the End of Fluid Infusion
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline; during the infusion (single bolus dose of hylenex [1 hr], followed by subcutaneous fluid for 1 hour to 72 hours)
secondary_outcome.description: Hydration status was assessed clinically using the Gorelick 10-item scale: general condition, quality of radial pulse, quality of respiration, skin elasticity, eyes, tears, mucous membranes, urine output, heart rate, and capillary refill time at the fingertip. Scores ranged from 0 (less severe impairment) to 10 (more severe impairment). Change from Baseline was calculated as the post-Baseline value minus the Baseline value.

secondary_outcome.measure: Percent Change From Baseline in Body Weight
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline; during the infusion (single bolus dose of hylenex [1 hr], followed by subcutaneous fluid for 1 hour to 72 hours)
secondary_outcome.description: Percent change from Baseline was calculated as the ([post-Baseline value minus the Baseline value] / Baseline value) * 100.

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of Participants With the Indicated Type of Rescue Route Therapy Administered
secondary_outcome.time_frame: During the infusion (single bolus dose of hylenex [1 hr], followed by subcutaneous fluid for 1 hour to 72 hours)
secondary_outcome.description: Participants for whom parenteral access by the randomized route of administration could not be achieved after a reasonable number of attempts and for whom the investigator had deemed the access by that route a failure were expected to receive fluid administration by other means, designated as "rescue route" for the purpose of this study. This rescue route may have included venous cut-down, central venous line, interosseous access, etc., and for those participants initially randomly assigned to IV fluid administration, SC fluid administration by hylenex-facilitated infusion.

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of Participants Classified With the Indicated Healthcare Provider Responses to the Questions Comprising the Healthcare Provider Global Satisfaction Questionnaire
secondary_outcome.time_frame: During the infusion (single bolus dose of hylenex [1 hr], followed by subcutaneous fluid for 1 hour to 72 hours)
secondary_outcome.description: A global assessment of overall satisfaction with the rehydration therapy by healthcare provider was performed at the end of SC or IV fluid rehydration utilizing a simple questionnaire. There were separate questionnaires for the two types of rehydration (SC and IV). Question 1: Was the participant successfully hydrated using the randomized route of administration?; Question 2: Overall, was the procedure of fluid infusion easy to perform?; Question 3: Were there any unacceptable side effects from the therapy?; Question 4: Would you consider using this hydration therapy for this indication in the future?

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of Participants Classified With the Indicated Healthcare Provider Responses to the Question: How Does This Therapy Compare to Your Experience With IV (for SC Group) / SC (for IV Group) Therapy?
secondary_outcome.time_frame: During the infusion (single bolus dose of hylenex [1 hr], followed by subcutaneous fluid for 1 hour to 72 hours)
secondary_outcome.description: A global assessment of overall satisfaction with the rehydration therapy by healthcare provider was performed at the end of SC or IV fluid rehydration utilizing a simple questionnaire. There were separate questionnaires for the two types of rehydration (SC and IV).

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of Participants Classified With the Indicated Parent/Guardian Responses to the Questions Comprising the Parent / Guardian Global Satisfaction Questionnaire
secondary_outcome.time_frame: During the infusion (single bolus dose of hylenex [1 hr], followed by subcutaneous fluid for 1 hour to 72 hours)
secondary_outcome.description: A global assessment of overall satisfaction with the rehydration therapy by healthcare provider was performed at the end of SC or IV fluid rehydration utilizing a simple questionnaire. There were separate questionnaires for the two types of rehydration (SC and IV). Question 1: Do you believe the method of therapy was successful in your child's rehydration?; Question 2: Have you or your child ever previously had IV fluids (for SC Group) / SC fluids (for IV Group)?; Question 3: If the response to Question 2 was "yes," how does this compare to prior experience with IV (for SC Group) / SC (for IV Group)?; Question 4: Should your child(ren) need rehydration treatment in the future, would you opt for this procedure?; Question 5: Should you need rehydration treatment in the future, would you opt for this procedure?; Question 6: What is your global satisfaction with the study procedure?

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of Participants With the Indicated Number of Different Anatomical Administration Sites Needed After the Start of Fluid Administration
secondary_outcome.time_frame: During the infusion (single bolus dose of hylenex [1 hr], followed by subcutaneous fluid for 1 hour to 72 hours)
secondary_outcome.description: In the event that the degree of local infusion site swelling became unacceptable for any reason (e.g., a 30% or greater increase from the baseline circumference of the infused thigh or in the clinical judgment of the investigator), the infusion rate was decreased or the infusion site was changed.

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of Participants Experiencing Reductions in Flow Rate
secondary_outcome.time_frame: During the infusion (single bolus dose of hylenex [1 hr], followed by subcutaneous fluid for 1 hour to 72 hours)
secondary_outcome.description: In the event that the degree of local infusion site swelling became unacceptable for any reason (e.g., a 30% or greater increase from the baseline circumference of the infused thigh or in the clinical judgment of the investigator), the infusion rate was decreased or the infusion site was changed.

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of Participants Who Received Needle Placement by People With the Indicated Level of Staff Training
secondary_outcome.time_frame: average of approximately 3 minutes
secondary_outcome.description: Data were collected for the level of staff training for the person who performed the needle placement.

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of Participants for Which the Indicated Number of Additional Personnel Was Involved in Needle Placement
secondary_outcome.time_frame: average of approximately 3 minutes
secondary_outcome.description: Data were collected for the number of additional personnel involved in needle placement.

secondary_outcome.measure: Time From the Start of Infusion to the Time of Emergency Department (ED) Discharge
secondary_outcome.time_frame: up to approximately 26 hours
secondary_outcome.description: Data are reported from the start of infusion to the time of ED discharge.

secondary_outcome.measure: Time From Randomization to the First Drop of Fluid Infusion
secondary_outcome.time_frame: up to approximately 110 and 220 minutes for the SC and IV arms, respectively
secondary_outcome.description: Data are reported for the time from randomization to the start of fluid infusion for all randomized participants.

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of Participants With the Indicated Number of Needle Stick Attempts Needed to Initiate Fluid Administration
secondary_outcome.time_frame: average of approximately 3 minutes
secondary_outcome.description: Data are reported for the number of needle stick attempts needed to initiate fluid administration.

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of Participants for Which the Indicated Type of Infusion Device Was Used
secondary_outcome.time_frame: average of approximately 3 minutes
secondary_outcome.description: Data are reported for the type of infusion device used.

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of Participants for Which the Indicated Gauge for Infusion Device Was Used
secondary_outcome.time_frame: average of approximately 3 minutes
secondary_outcome.description: Data are reported for the gauge of infusion device used.

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of Participants Discharged From the ED to Home or the Hospital
secondary_outcome.time_frame: up to approximately 26 hours
secondary_outcome.description: Participants were discharged from the ED to home or the hospital to continue hydration therapy.

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of Participants With the Indicated Reason for Rehospitalization Within 48 and 72 Hours After Discharge
secondary_outcome.time_frame: from randomization up to approximately 98 hours
secondary_outcome.description: Participants were discharged from the ED to home or the hospital to continue hydration therapy.

arm_group.description: Isotonic fluid rehydration by SC administration with hylenex (150 Units in 1 mL)

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Children of either gender from one month to ≤10 years of age.
- Patients with mild or moderate dehydration
- Healthy child except for the underlying etiology for dehydration
- Pre-dehydration body weight ≥ 5th percentile for age
- Parents or legal guardian(s) available to provide informed consent.
Exclusion Criteria:
- Severe dehydration
- Shock or life-threatening situation (life expectancy < 10 days).
- Requirement for IV access for any indication other than for treatment of dehydration.
- Indwelling IV catheter, except for one intended only for collection of clinical laboratory specimens.
- Any condition precluding SC infusion or infusion site evaluation
- Any reason (prior to study enrollment) for a hospital admission or an extended stay in the ED for other than dehydration.
- Known hypersensitivity to hyaluronidase or hylenex.
- Known hyponatremia (< 130 milliequivalents per liter [mEq/L]) or hypernatremia (> 155 mEq/L).
- Known hypokalemia (< 3.0 mEq/L).
- Any medical condition likely to interfere with the patient's ability to fully complete all protocol-specified interventions, the ability to undergo all protocol-specified assessments, or likely to prolong the patient's need for medical attention beyond that required for treatment of dehydration.
- Participation in an investigational drug or device study within 30 days prior to enrollment in this study.

analysis.non_inferiority_desc: Subcutaneous administration would not be deemed as inferior if the volume infused subcutaneous is ≥85% of the volume infused intravenously.
analysis.p_value_desc: P-value for the test of the null hypothesis that the volume delivered via a hylenex-facilitated subcutaneous infusion was ≤85% of the volume delivered intravenously.

For participants who received fluid at more than one administration site, a single infusion site was defined as the anatomical site at which the majority of the total infusion volume was infused. The term "anatomical site" was designated as: 1) the back; 2) left thigh; 3) right thigh; 4) abdomen; or 5) chest. Participants randomized to receive intravenous isotonic fluid were permitted to receive subcutaneous fluid administration by hylenex-facilitated infusion as rescue.
measure.population: ITT Population. Only those participants for which fluid administration was initiated were analyzed. Only those participants randomized to receive intravenous isotonic fluid who received subcutaneous fluid administration by hylenex-facilitated infusion as rescue were analyzed.

outcome.title: Mean Total Volume of Fluid Administered at All Infusion Sites, From the Start to the Cessation of Fluid Administration, for All Randomized Participants Achieving > 200 mL
outcome.description: It was anticipated that most participants in this study would be hydrated through only one infusion site. For participants who received fluid at more than one administration site, a single infusion site was defined as the anatomical site at which the majority of the total infusion volume was infused. The term "anatomical site" was designated as: 1) the back; 2) left thigh; 3) right thigh; 4) abdomen; or 5) chest. The label for hylenex indicated precautionary wording recommending an upper limit on the volume of fluid (200 mL) administered subcutaneously to infants less than 3 years of age. In October 2008, the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) removed this wording from the label, thus negating the need for these data and associated analyses. The protocol was amended to reflect this label change; thus, this analysis was not conducted.

outcome.description: Adverse events (AEs) are defined as any untoward medical occurrence in a participant administered a product, which did not necessarily have a causal relationship with the treatment. outcome.title: Mean Change From Baseline in the Face, Legs, Activity, Cry, Consolability (FLACC) Pain Scale Score
outcome.description: The infusion site was assessed for pain at two time points: after placement of the infusion device but before fluid infusion and at the end of infusion. Pain was recorded using the FLACC pain scale for children less than 3 years of age. Scores on the scale ranged from 0 (no hurt) to 10 (hurt worst).

measure.title: Mean Change From Baseline in the Face, Legs, Activity, Cry, Consolability (FLACC) Pain Scale Score
measure.description: The infusion site was assessed for pain at two time points: after placement of the infusion device but before fluid infusion and at the end of infusion. Pain was recorded using the FLACC pain scale for children less than 3 years of age. Scores on the scale ranged from 0 (no hurt) to 10 (hurt worst).
measure.population: Safety Population. Only those participants with available data were analyzed.

outcome.title: Change From Baseline in Hydration Status According to the Gorelick Assessment at the End of Fluid Infusion
outcome.description: Hydration status was assessed clinically using the Gorelick 10-item scale: general condition, quality of radial pulse, quality of respiration, skin elasticity, eyes, tears, mucous membranes, urine output, heart rate, and capillary refill time at the fingertip. Scores ranged from 0 (less severe impairment) to 10 (more severe impairment). Change from Baseline was calculated as the post-Baseline value minus the Baseline value.
outcome.time_frame: Baseline; during the infusion (single bolus dose of hylenex [1 hr], followed by subcutaneous fluid for 1 hour to 72 hours)
outcome.population: ITT Population. Only those participants contributing data at the indicated time point were assessed.

outcome.title: Number of Participants With the Indicated Type of Rescue Route Therapy Administered
outcome.description: Participants for whom parenteral access by the randomized route of administration could not be achieved after a reasonable number of attempts and for whom the investigator had deemed the access by that route a failure were expected to receive fluid administration by other means, designated as "rescue route" for the purpose of this study. This rescue route may have included venous cut-down, central venous line, interosseous access, etc., and for those participants initially randomly assigned to IV fluid administration, SC fluid administration by hylenex-facilitated infusion.
outcome.time_frame: During the infusion (single bolus dose of hylenex [1 hr], followed by subcutaneous fluid for 1 hour to 72 hours)
outcome.population: ITT Population

outcome.title: Number of Participants Classified With the Indicated Healthcare Provider Responses to the Questions Comprising the Healthcare Provider Global Satisfaction Questionnaire
outcome.description: A global assessment of overall satisfaction with the rehydration therapy by healthcare provider was performed at the end of SC or IV fluid rehydration utilizing a simple questionnaire. There were separate questionnaires for the two types of rehydration (SC and IV). Question 1: Was the participant successfully hydrated using the randomized route of administration?; Question 2: Overall, was the procedure of fluid infusion easy to perform?; Question 3: Were there any unacceptable side effects from the therapy?; Question 4: Would you consider using this hydration therapy for this indication in the future?
outcome.time_frame: During the infusion (single bolus dose of hylenex [1 hr], followed by subcutaneous fluid for 1 hour to 72 hours)

outcome.title: Number of Participants Classified With the Indicated Parent/Guardian Responses to the Questions Comprising the Parent / Guardian Global Satisfaction Questionnaire
outcome.description: A global assessment of overall satisfaction with the rehydration therapy by healthcare provider was performed at the end of SC or IV fluid rehydration utilizing a simple questionnaire. There were separate questionnaires for the two types of rehydration (SC and IV). Question 1: Do you believe the method of therapy was successful in your child's rehydration?; Question 2: Have you or your child ever previously had IV fluids (for SC Group) / SC fluids (for IV Group)?; Question 3: If the response to Question 2 was "yes," how does this compare to prior experience with IV (for SC Group) / SC (for IV Group)?; Question 4: Should your child(ren) need rehydration treatment in the future, would you opt for this procedure?; Question 5: Should you need rehydration treatment in the future, would you opt for this procedure?; Question 6: What is your global satisfaction with the study procedure?
outcome.time_frame: During the infusion (single bolus dose of hylenex [1 hr], followed by subcutaneous fluid for 1 hour to 72 hours)
outcome.population: ITT Population. Only participants with a response of "Yes" to Question 2 contributed responses for Question 3.
